lg.l: NEW WORLD. New World. Mignon is a character in Johann Wolfgang von Goethe’s Wilhelm Meister’s Apprenticeship (1795-6), who has been kidnapped from her native land of Italy and brought to Germany. Wilson’s poem translates Mignon’s homeland to the “New World” of New Zealand.

Know’st thou an island Know’st thou an island. Mignon’s song begins, “Kennst du das Land?,” which nineteenth-century translators rendered as “Know’st thou the land” (F. Hemans, National Lyrics, and Songs for Music, 1834). on the misty ocean,
Green, green with fern, and many an ancient tree,
Whose waving tops, with soft perpetual motion
Repeat the same primeval melody?

The rata Rata. A species of tree, infamous for beginning its life as an epiphyte that strangles its host tree as its roots grow down to the ground. with the red pine Red pine. Rimu is a tall forest tree, and the poem imagines rata in its epiphytic form sending roots down from its branches. interlaces,
And lights the forest with a scarlet gleam.
The sunshine on the hills the shadow chases;
The fern-tree bends in silence o’er the stream.
I see the harvest slopes; the village under;
The rivulet lifts its music on the air.
Hearing far off the turbulent ocean-thunder,
It leaps in laughter down its rocky stair.
There is the snow-king’s palace and dominion! Snow-king’s palace and dominion. In Goethe’s poem, Mignon asks, “Know’st thou the mountain?” (F. Hemans, National Lyrics, and Songs for Music, 1834).
Unchanged in summer’s glow and winter rain,
With frozen wings outspread, and icy pinion,
He floats above the level pastoral plain. Level pastoral plain. Wilson and her husband lived and farmed on the Manawatū plains, in view of the Tararua mountain range.
Motionless, voiceless, pallid, yet immortal!
While far below the cloudy seasons roll;
Meeting the day, and night’s slow-closing portal,
He reads the ever-changing starry scroll.
Oh there, beloved! There if we might wander,
Leaving this world of noisy hopes and fears,
Drink of the fount of youth that rises yonder,
And all forget our shadow-laden years!
